Dear @Diego26,

in CBC please check if you have unlocked the types below (Configure Condition Contract Types for Customer Condition Contracts: 102215), correct value = Not Blocked - Can be Used.

You may encounter a lack of permissions, so in case of problems, add the following in the Maintain Business Role:

More details below:

entry.title: Re: Title: API for Supplier Master and Supplier Bank Acco...
entry.content:
Dear @byd,

Yes in Public Cloud you do have standard APIs for both supplier master and supplier bank data. Everything is driven via Business Partner.

Supplier master creation and update:

The main API is: OData (recommended)

API name:
Business Partner (A2X) – technical name API_BUSINESS_PARTNER

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/85043858ea0f9244e10000000a4450e5.html

https://api.sap.com/package/SAPS4HANACloud/odata

 

What it can do:

This single OData service lets you create, read, update, delete master data for:

  • Business Partner header (A_BusinessPartner)
  • Supplier core data (A_Supplier)
  • Supplier company data (A_SupplierCompany)
  • Supplier purchasing data (A_SupplierPurchasingOrg)
  • Business partner roles (A_BusinessPartnerRole)

More details below from SAP Help and SAP Community for Custom Fields:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/1e488b3c40ff4ed3a96be20d3850b26d.html

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/add-custom-fields-to-sap-s-4hana-business-partner-odata-api-entities/ba-p/13333784

So for a typical create or update supplier scenario you:

  1. Create / update the Business Partner header
    • POST /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/A_BusinessPartner (create)
    • PATCH /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/A_BusinessPartner('<BP>') (update)
  2. Assign supplier roles to that BP
    • POST .../A_BusinessPartner('<BP>')/to_BusinessPartnerRole
    • Use roles like FLVN00 (FI vendor) / FLVN01 (supplier) depending on your design.
  3. Maintain supplier-specific data
    • A_Supplier – core supplier data
    • A_SupplierCompany – reconciliation account, payment terms, etc. per company code
    • A_SupplierPurchasingOrg – purchasing org data (order currency, incoterms, etc.)

For your integration use case (external system maintaining suppliers) this OData API is the standard and recommended approach in Public Cloud.

Supplier bank account maintenance:

Bank data is also covered by the same Business Partner (A2X) service there is no separate Supplier Bank API.

API_BUSINESS_PARTNER you have the entity:

  • A_BusinessPartnerBank – BusinessPartnerBank

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/5d5e045826552246e10000000a441470.html

It contains fields such as:

  • Business partner
  • Bank country
  • Bank account / IBAN

Typical operations:

  • Create bank account for a supplier BP
    POST /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/A_BusinessPartnerBank
  • Update bank account
    PATCH /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/A_BusinessPartnerBank(BusinessPartner='<BP>',BankIdentification='<ID>')


The bank itself is separate and managed via Manage Banks Master Data app. Your supplier’s bank account record in A_BusinessPartnerBank references that bank by country and bank key / ID.

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F6437')/S35

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/f86dc2eb1f8b48c880a7607213104b27/0e2291626ec34988876ef0217355460d.html

How to set it up in Public Cloud:

The high-level steps:

  1. Create Communication User and System (Fiori apps: Maintain Communication Users, Communication Systems).

More details below:

https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/abap-environment-business-partner-basic-auth..html

  1. Create Communication Arrangement for SAP_COM_0008
    • This exposes Business Partner (A2X) OData as inbound service.
  2. Use the generated service URL like:
    https://<your-tenant>/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/ in your integration.

https://api.sap.com/api/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/resource/get_A_BusinessPartner

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Message and Header exchange from Child to Parent flows

entry.title: Duplicate Candidate Rows in People Story Recruiting Report
entry.content:
I'm building a People Story report to analyze recruiting metrics such as time to hire, time to fill, recruiting time, etc., using various date fields (e.g., requisition created, offer created/approved, application created). Attached is the query design.

When reporting on multi-vacancy requisitions, the table in the report displays candidates in multiple rows. For example, if a requisition has five positions and each is filled by a different candidate, the table lists each candidate for every position—resulting in 25 rows instead of 5 (each candidate appears multiple times).

Each candidate should appear in the report once, associated only with the specific position they have filled.

What could be causing these duplicate entries? How can I adjust my report or data join so that each candidate appears just once, matched to their filled position?

entry.title: Re: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
Hi @DianaRoesner ,

I appreciate the new approach to the certification exams, where the focus is on practical application rather than memorization. This method aligns well with real-world scenarios and is a positive step forward.

I have attempted the SAP Generative AI Developer certification exam twice under the new system-based approach, prior to its recent rework. I currently have an open case with the SAP Support team (Case ID: 5000243946), but I have not received any updates for over a week. After my first attempt, I received a “Failed” status in my certifications tab; however, for the second attempt, no remarks or status were provided.

While I appreciate this innovative approach, I would like to share some feedback and request timely resolution so that users’ attempts are not wasted:

  1. Exam Bugs:

    • In one task, the system required saving a template with the name “optimal model configuration”. However, after changing the template name, the system did not allow saving.

  2. Result Transparency:

    • Currently, the exam only provides a Pass/Fail status. It would be highly beneficial to include details on which tasks were unsuccessful, so candidates can identify areas for improvement.

  3. Learning Resources:

    • The existing learning journey does not provide sufficient material to help candidates understand and correct their mistakes.

  4. Human Review Option:

    • Introducing an option for human review of the exam would be extremely helpful. Personalized feedback on why a candidate failed would allow targeted improvement for future attempts.
  5. Template Issue in Final Exercise: 
  • In the last exercise of the current exam, the instructions require using template version 3.1.0 for an orchestration flow. However, this template contains pre-filled data in the Assistant tab, which results in no outcome after running the orchestration workflow.

I hope these points are helpful in enhancing the overall experience.

entry.title: SAP BTP ABAP Environment - Release 2511
entry.content:
SAP BTP ABAP Environment - Release 2511

With the introduction of the new release 2511, this blog post presents an overview of the latest features and enhancements. The release has been available since November 15th and serves as the successor to the release 2508. Some highlights of the 2511 release include the Analytical table with RAP and SAP Fiori Elements, the ADT editor for Business Configuration Sets and the Graphical Modeler for CDS. 

The list of all new features can be found on the What's New for SAP BTP ABAP Environment page

ABAP Development Tools (ADT)

  • Using ghost text as new default for keyword completion, when you start typing a keyword, ADT now shows the best matching suggestion as ghost text at the current position within your source code by default (details)
  • Editor for E-Mail templates, it allows the creation of pre-delivered e-mail templates for rendering e-mails using said templates or for further template copies created with the SAP Fiori app Maintain E-Mail Templates in different languages (details)
  • Editor for Business Configuration Sets (details)
  • ADT Objects for SAP Application Interface Framework (details)
  • Enhancements in the Dependency Analyzer for CDS Table Functions (details)
  • Support of Graphical Call Timeline on macOS for ABAP Traces (details)
  • Logon with Versions of ADT Older than 3.46 no Longer Possible

ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP)

  • Log RAP-based change documents, this feature enables the logging of RAP-based customer-defined change documents as business events in business event logging (details)
  • RAP change operations for data records, with the introduction of the new syntax addition read entity MyEntity with changes (all fields | fields ( ... ) ) with ... result data(rdc), an application developer may now access the corresponding change operations of a data record processed within the transaction
  • RAP global side effects, they are an optional part of a RAP behavior definition that define interdependencies among BO properties that trigger a reload of the affected properties on the user interface. Global side effects are those side effects that are defined without any source properties or source entities and can be invoked by an end user with a dedicated key stroke

SAP Fiori

  • Fiori Analytical Table - Read-Only, you miss the ABAP List Viewer (ALV) in Fiori with simple analytical capabilities? The Fiori Analytical Table will be introduced to combine the transactional and light-weight analytical world. RAP needs to support further OData URL to ABAP SQL mapping with analytical capabilities. For advanced analytics with multi-dimensional analytical reporting please check the analytical clients

Business Configuration

  • Support of Business Configuration Sets with a new ADT editor (see above) and new released API to extract the business configuration data in target tenants (details)
  • Hide draft related features, all features related to draft handling can be hidden from the UI while the draft functionality remains active in the background (details)

Integration

  • Predefined custom fields, you can now add predefined custom fields to OData consumption models (details)
  • New CDS views in business event logging, the following CDS views have been released: Business Event Header Data, Business Event Payload, Business Event Data, Business Event Activity (see Business Event Header Data, Business Event Payload, Business Event Data, Business Activity)
  • RFC communication via communication targets, a new enhancement in RFC communication introduces the use of communication targets and application destinations for outbound RFC communication. This ensures more secure and efficient communication processes

Event Consumption Model

  • Button Publish Locally for EEEC authorizations, the Publish Locally button in the event consumption model allows users to generate authorizations for the EEEC within the SAP_BR_DEVELOPER role (details)

Reuse Services

  • You can now reset content to the standard units of measurement delivered by SAP using the released API CL_UOM_CONTENT_HANDLER (details)
  • You can now convert SAP codes to external codes and vice versa using class CL_CONVERSION_EXT_INT (details)

XCO Library

  • You can now create, read, update, and delete business configuration sets with the XCO API (details)
  • You can now generate static external entities
  • You can now also customize the borders of individual cells using the Excel API

Maintain Translations

  • You can now use the Maintain Translations app for custom translations of application job entities. Additionally, we've removed the limit on the total amount of texts you can add and translate in a translation project. You can now add an unlimited number of texts (details)

ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC)

  • Partner support in ATC check "Usage of APIs", when using an SAP BTP ABAP environment as the central check system, the ATC check Usage of APIs allows you to specify classic APIs of SAP partners. This enables customers to improve their custom code with regards to Clean Core compliance when using APIs of certified SAP partners
  • Approve ATC Exemptions App: Receive E-Mail notifications, you can now subscribe to receive e-mail notifications when an ATC exemption request was approved (details)

Lifecycle Management

  • Manage Software Components, Software Components configured with the role Target are now protected from changes and cannot be recorded on transports. This feature is designed to prevent inadvertent modifications to components, ensuring their integrity and stability (details)
  • Manage Software Components, you can now use the safe remote deletion feature. It is designed to ensure system integrity by preventing the accidental deletion of active repositories or branches and prevents the creation of ghost software components (details)

Technical Monitoring

  • Capturing of PlanViz (PLV) files now possible in the Capture Request Statistics app, and subsequent download in the SQL Statement Analysis app (details)

entry.title: Common configuration issues: Joule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Let's look at the common issues that we may have while setting up Joule with SuccessFactors:

  1. SAP BTP Booster | Entitlements Missing
  2. SAP BTP Booster | Sync between Joule and SAP Cloud Identity Services System failed
  3. SAP BTP Booster | No Registered Systems of type S/4HANA
  4. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud | Joule icon missing in S/4HANA Cloud
  5. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud | Some Prompts are Not Working
  6. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud |  Not Authorised

==================================================================================

So let us take a look at the issue and how to fix them:

1. SAP BTP Booster | Entitlements Missing

While running the booster, we got the error message:

“Some of the entitlements are not available in the selected subaccount <XXXX>. Please either add them or select a subaccount with different provider or region.”

Fix: 

Go to BTP Global Account -> Entity Assignments.

Check if Joule and SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition service are entitled to the subaccount.

If Joule is not available in BTP Global Account -> Procure Joule

 

2. SAP BTP Booster | Sync between Joule and SAP Cloud Identity Services System failed

While running the Joule booster, we got the error message:

 

Fix: Please follow the KBA to setup accordingly: 

3539985 - Synchronization failed between Joule and SAP Cloud Identity Services when using booster for Joule setup

 

3. SAP BTP Booster | No Registered Systems of type S/4HANA

While running the booster, we got the error message:

Cause: S/4HANA system is not registered with BTP global account.

Fix: Double check the steps “Register SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition in BTP Global Account” in the mission.

 

4. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud | Joule icon missing in S/4HANA Cloud

There are several reasons might cause this issue, please follow below to check:

4.1 Double check the step “Update Content Security Policy Settings in S/4HANA Cloud” in mission

Follow the last step to paste the URL of your Joule application into the Trusted Content text box and click Save.

4. 2  Try opening the system in an Incognito window to rule out browser cache issues.
If Joule appears there, clear your browser cache and cookies before accessing it again in normal mode.

4.3 When logging int S/4HANA Public Cloud, check the domain of Cloud Identity Services that is used during login (e.g. ending with ondemand.com or cloud.sap) => in BTP Cockpit -> Joule Subaccount -> Trust Configuration -> Select the Cloud Identity Services used for application logon -> check if the “Domain” is set to the same domain used in S4.

4.4 Check in Cloud Identity Services if the hosting application (S/4Public Cloud) and Joule application are configured in exact same way (IDP/Conditional authentication)

 

5. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud | Some Prompts are Not Working

5.1 Cause: CDM content not synchronised

Fix: In the Channel Manager of Build Workzone, please click on "Report" to check how many apps / roles were actually synchronised.

5. 2 Cause: User lacking role assignments.

Fix:  Check whether the logged in user actually have the required groups assigned.

Check the sample prompts and corresponding roles here.

5. 3 Double check below steps in the mission

  • Provision Users and Groups from S/4HANA Cloud to Work Zone
  • Update Content Security Policy Settings in S/4HANA Cloud

6. Joule in S/4HANA Cloud |  Not Authorised

Cause: In rare cases the automated integration between Joule and S/4HANA might fail.

Fix: Check if the CN name used in Destination S4HANA_PUB_SSO fits to the CN name maintained in S/4HANA.
In case of mismatch open an incident with CA-JOULE

CN name in above screenshot need to match between BTP Destination and S/4 Communication System (Signing Certificate Issuer in below screenshot).

 

If the issue still persists or any other issues not listed here, open a ticket under component CA-JOULE.

 

Cheers, 

Happy Learning

SAP Business AI RIG team

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Paraguay CDE 2025: Planificación Financiera Consolidada y Procesamiento de Facturas
entry.content:
El SAP Inside Track Paraguay SITCDE2025 nos trajo una presentación reveladora de la mano de Juan José Torres, quien compartió soluciones concretas para dos desafíos críticos que enfrentan las empresas con SAP: la automatización del procesamiento de facturas electrónicas y la contabilidad orientada a unidades de negocio.


El Desafío de la Facturación Electrónica: Volumen Creciente, Tiempo Limitado
Juan José comenzó con una realidad contundente: los volúmenes de facturación electrónica están creciendo mes a mes en Paraguay, y la DNIT reporta cifras cada vez más altas de documentos electrónicos aprobados. Esto genera un desafío operativo significativo para las empresas.
"En países como Chile, si una factura emitida no fue rechazada a las 72 horas, ya empiezan a correr los tiempos de mora. Acá todavía no está aplicado, pero en cualquier momento se viene."
El problema más común: contabilidad centraliza las cargas de facturas, muchas veces las deja para los últimos días del mes, no se toma el crédito fiscal a tiempo, y se generan problemas para el cierre contable. La solución es clara: automatización.

La Solución: Automatización Inteligente de Facturas
La propuesta presentada trabaja sobre cualquier versión de SAP y se basa en tres componentes clave:
Lectura Automatizada

  • Un robot lee los emails con facturas electrónicas
  • Una aplicación procesa el QR de la factura paraguaya (trabaja con XML, no con OCR)
  • Se ingresa a SAP a través de IDOC

Validaciones Inteligentes La solución no solo carga facturas, sino que valida:

  • Mapeo automático del RUC del emisor al código de proveedor en SAP
  • Concordancia con órdenes de compra abiertas
  • Lectura del cuerpo del mail para identificar el número de orden de compra
  • Determinación del centro de costos basado en sucursales
  • Validación de condiciones de pago e indicadores de impuestos

Rechazo Automático Inteligente
Si la factura no cumple con las reglas de negocio (por ejemplo, no declara una orden de compra válida), el sistema la rechaza automáticamente con el listado de órdenes de compra disponibles para que el proveedor reenvíe el mail. Esto evita el trabajo manual de análisis y respuesta.
Beneficios Concretos La implementación de esta solución, que actualmente están desplegando en empresas de Paraguay, genera:

  • Aceleración de procesos de cierre contable
  • Descentralización de la carga (logística puede cargar facturas directamente)
  • Validación del CDC en la página de la DNIT desde la transacción estándar de SAP
  • Reducción del papeleo
  • Circuitos de aprobación más ágiles

Contabilidad Orientada a Unidades de Negocio: El Ferrari sin Usar
La segunda parte de la presentación tocó un punto crítico que Juan José identificó en múltiples implementaciones:
"Cada vez que conozco un cliente nuevo, le pregunto: ¿Cuál es tu estado de resultados por marca? ¿Cuál es tu margen por marca? Y no lo sabe, o tiene que andar sacando muchos Excel."
El diagnóstico es claro: muchas empresas tienen el centro de beneficios mal armado. El centro de beneficios es el dato que consolida todo lo que corresponde al estado de resultados: gastos, ventas y costos directos.

La Propuesta: ROADMAP Analytics
Para resolver esto, la solución presentada es Roadmap Analytics, construida sobre SAP Analytics Cloud en entorno S/4HANA:
Concepto Clave
Levanta toda la información del estado de resultados en la memoria de HANA y deriva las dimensiones a partir del documento contable. Es similar al antiguo módulo COPA (análisis de rentabilidad), pero sin necesidad de crear tablas físicas nuevas.
Antes vs Ahora

Antes: Crear tablas físicas en el sistema con características e indicadores específicos
Ahora: Derivaciones en memoria cuando se levanta el cubo de análisis

Capacidades
Análisis Multidimensional: Estado de resultados por cliente, línea de negocio, sucursal, marca
Planificación Consolidada: Integra planificación de gastos por centro de costos con planificación de ingresos y costos por centro de beneficios
Dashboards Ejecutivos: Desplegables en BTP con análisis de plan vs real
Reportes Descargables: Estados de resultados en Excel con la información consolidada

El Caso Real: Transformación en Horas
Juan José compartió un ejemplo reciente en Paraguay donde cambiaron la estructura de centros de beneficio de una empresa:
"Ahorramos horas de trabajo de cierre de mes para reportes básicos como la rentabilidad de la empresa por unidad de negocio. No lo tenía cubierto una empresa que tiene SAP hace más de 10 años."

El Mensaje de Fondo

"Muchas veces SAP te da una Ferrari, pero no la usan. Tienen la funcionalidad, pero no la están aprovechando."

La presentación dejó en claro que no se trata solo de implementar SAP, sino de aprovechar sus capacidades reales. Ya sea automatizando el procesamiento de facturas electrónicas para responder a los desafíos regulatorios y de volumen, o configurando correctamente los centros de beneficio para tener visibilidad real del negocio.

Ambas soluciones están pensadas para S/4HANA y representan la evolución natural de funcionalidades que SAP ha tenido durante años, pero que ahora, con la potencia de HANA y la integración con BTP, pueden implementarse de manera más ágil y efectiva.

¿Tu empresa está aprovechando el potencial completo de su inversión en SAP?

Gracias a Juan José Torres por compartir su experiencia y conocimiento, y al equipo organizador del SAP Inside Track Paraguay por crear estos espacios de intercambio. #SITCDE2025

entry.title: Re: New to SAP in Accounts Payable — What Should I Learn...
entry.content:
Good morning sir , 

First you can try to look at the "Company Code" view of the vendor mater data , try to understand how does the "Payment term" and "Reconciliation Account" work .  Then you can try to learn about how to do the payment process (t-code : F-53 or F-44 ) to clear AP line item , sometimes we also use "Automatic Payment" function (t-code: F110) you can check how to use these t-code from the internet . 

Next you should learn about General ledger , this is not too hard .

After you know the outline about all FI-AP , FI-GL , and maybe a little FI-AR , you can start to learn about the integration between MM module and FI module . First you can learn about the standard purchasing business flow in SAP , generally there are 3 steps : 1.Create Purchase Order --> 2.Goods Receipt --> 3.Invoice Receipt . Only step 2 and 3 will generate FI document , about this you can search on the internet there are many posts about this . After you know the standard flow in SAP , you can try to study how your company is doing it , see the FI document flow in your purchasing flow . There is an important concept : "GR/IR Account" , please also search it on the internet . 

After you understand your business flow , you can try to study the monthly closing process and yearly closing process for your accounting department .

maybe you can also learn about Material master data , how does it work in purchase order , and how does it influence FI module .

regards

Shi Zhekui

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Paraguay CDE 2025: Transformación Ágil - Cómo Acompañar el Cambio en la Era de SAP
entry.content:
Del Control Técnico a la Transformación Ágil - Cómo Acompañar el Cambio en la Era de SAP
El SAP Inside Track Paraguay SITCDE2025 contó con una presentación reveladora de Esteban Hartzstein, Director y Fundador de Tebyon Consulting, quien con más de 30 años de experiencia trabajando con SAP, compartió una reflexión contundente: existe una enorme brecha entre lo que SAP desarrolla en Alemania y lo que realmente se implementa en Latinoamérica.


La Pregunta Incómoda: ¿Seguimos en 2008?
Recién llegado del ALM Summit 2025 en Alemania, Esteban fue directo: "Hay una desconexión entre lo que pasa en los product managers que están desarrollando los productos SAP y lo que se termina implementando en las empresas. Seguimos viendo implementaciones que parecen de los años 90."
Los problemas recurrentes:

  • Se implementan como ERPs tradicionales, no se conocen los procesos estándares
  • Demasiados gaps y desarrollos Z sin valor real
  • Falta de metodología: "¿Con Excel y PowerPoint alcanza? No alcanza"
  • Desconocimiento de herramientas como Signavio Process Navigator y Cloud ALM
  • Datos poco limpios, testing deficiente, cutovers problemáticos

SAP BTM y SAP ALM: Los Conceptos Clave
SAP Business Transformation Management (BTM) es el enfoque metodológico que combina cuatro ejes: Estrategia y Valores, Procesos y Arquitectura, Programas y Proyectos, y Personas y Culturas.
SAP Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) gestiona todo el ciclo de vida de las aplicaciones: Implementación (Design, Build, Test, Deploy), Operación (Detect, Analyze, Correct, Automate), Mejora Continua y Servicios.


La Toolchain Integrada: El Nuevo Paradigma
SAP ha evolucionado de un sistema monolítico a una cadena de herramientas especializadas e integradas:

  • SAP LeanIX: Arquitectura empresarial
  • SAP Signavio: Gestión de procesos
  • SAP Cloud ALM: Implementación y operaciones (el orquestador central)
  • WalkMe/EnableNow: Adopción digital

SAP Cloud ALM: Gratuito, Potente y Subutilizado
Esteban enfatizó: "Todos los proyectos deberían estar usando Cloud ALM. Es un producto gratuito entregado por SAP, se habilita rapidamente y está en la nube."
Números que impresionan:

  • 2020: 250 clientes
  • 2025: +10,000 clientes proyectados

Capacidades de implementación:
Project & Task Management, Process Management, Documentation, Test Orchestration, Test Execution, Deployment Orchestration, Change Enablement.
Capacidades operativas:
Business Process Monitoring con KPIs predefinidos, Job & Automation Monitoring, Integration Monitoring, Health Monitoring, Real User Monitoring, Configuration & Security Analysis - todo con procesamiento inteligente mediante IA (Joule).

Clean Core: Los 5 Principios para Sistemas Ágiles
SAP Clean Core garantiza que los sistemas se mantengan ágiles y rentables:

  1. Business Processes: Usar estándares sin modificar el core
  2. Extensibility: Desacoplar extensiones (desarrollar en BTP)
  3. Data: Controlar datos según últimos estándares
  4. Integration: Mantener el landscape confiable y flexible
  5. Operations: Operaciones efectivas y eficientes

El Mensaje: Aprovechemos lo que SAP Ya nos Dio
Las recomendaciones finales de Esteban fueron claras:

  • Entiendan los procesos de negocio actuales antes de implementar
  • Planifiquen la arquitectura empresarial
  • Modelen procesos To-Be basados en estándares SAP
  • Usen SAP Activate y trabajen con sprints
  • Aprovechen Cloud ALM gratuito para gestión de proyectos
  • Operen con monitoreo inteligente
  • Consulten a especialistas - no todas las consultoras tienen el conocimiento necesario

Reflexión Final
"Cloud ALM lo tienen todos gratuito. Signavio puede ser que tengan alguna versión incluida. Las herramientas están disponibles, la metodología está documentada."
La pregunta no es si SAP tiene las herramientas y metodologías - las tiene, están documentadas y muchas son gratuitas. La pregunta es: ¿estamos aprovechando todo lo que SAP ha preparado para nosotros, o seguimos implementando como en 2008?
El cambio de era en SAP no es solo tecnológico - es metodológico y cultural. Requiere que clientes, consultores y partners demos un paso adelante hacia la verdadera transformación empresarial.

Gracias a Esteban Hartzstein y Tebyon Consulting  por compartir su experiencia del ALM Summit 2025 en Alemania, y al equipo organizador del SAP Inside Track Paraguay.

entry.title: Re: Enable Now – Table of contents and audio integration...
entry.content:
Hi team Wibke,

It is not possible to create links to internal sections of a scrollable page.  Unfortunately, the HTML cleaner in Enable Now modifies the links, including internal links, and the modified version of the link does not work if the link is to another section of the same page.

It would be possible to play different audio as the user scrolls down the page, however, you will have to consider the best way to trigger that audio.  Using Enable Now, you can add multiple audio files to a single page and then trigger the relevant audio for the corresponding section.

 

 

 

The easiest way that I can think to trigger the audio is to get users to play it when they are ready.  You could easily do that by adding buttons to the page, at the relevant points, and setting up an action to play the relevant piece of audio when the user clicks the corresponding button.

 

 

 

Hope that helps.

Regards
Shane

entry.title: Introduction to API in SAP ABAP
entry.content:
Introduction to REST APIs in SAP ABAP – A Beginner-Friendly Guide

In today’s digital landscape, integration is at the heart of every business process. Whether it’s connecting SAP with e-commerce platforms, CRMs, payment gateways, or cloud applications—APIs play a crucial role in making systems communicate smoothly and securely.

As SAP evolves, an ABAP developer is no longer limited to classical reports and enhancements.

We now work in a world where REST APIs, JSON payloads, and HTTP calls are becoming everyday essentials.

This blog marks Part 1 of my API Series for SAP Developers, where I break down core API concepts in simple words, along with how they relate to SAP ABAP.

What is an API? 

  • API stands for Application Programming Interface—a structured way for two systems to communicate.

Think of an API as a messenger that carries a request from one system and brings back a response from another.

For example:

  • SAP retrieving live weather details from a weather API
  • SAP sending order data to a third-party logistics system
  • SAP fetching exchange rates from an external service

Understanding REST and RESTful APIs

  • REST (Representational State Transfer) is an architectural style that defines how systems interact using simple, lightweight standards—usually over HTTP.

A REST API follows these REST principles and works on the basis of:

➡️ A Request sent by the client

➡️ A Response returned by the server

This makes REST APIs fast, scalable, and widely used.

Structure of an API Request

A typical API request consists of four key elements:

1. Endpoint

  • The URL where the request is sent.

Example: /weather/data/city=Berlin

2. Method (HTTP Verb)

  • Defines the action to perform.

Method Purpose:

  1. GET Retrieve data
  2. POST Create new data
  3. PUT Replace/update full data
  4. PATCH Update partial data
  5. DELETE Remove data

3. Headers

  • Used for authentication (API key, bearer token) and metadata (content type, encoding).

4. Body (Payload)

  • The actual data being sent—usually JSON or XML.

Example (JSON):

{

  "city": "Berlin",

  "unit": "celsius"

}

Prerequisites in SAP to Consume an API:

  • Before calling an API from SAP ABAP, ensure:
  • ✔ SICF Service is Active
  • SAP uses ICF (Internet Communication Framework) for HTTP/HTTPS calls.
  • Transaction: SICF
  • ✔ Required Authorizations
  • Your user should have permissions for:
  • Making HTTP calls
  • Accessing destinations
  • Using classes like CL_HTTP_CLIENT

How SAP ABAP Communicates with APIs:

API provides robust classes to make HTTP calls:

  • CL_HTTP_CLIENT – Create and send requests
  • IF_HTTP_CLIENT – Handle and process responses

With these, you can:

✔ Send GET/POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE calls

✔ Send JSON/XML body

✔ Read and parse JSON responses

✔ Connect SAP to external cloud services

This opens doors to integrations like:

  •  Fetching weather data
  • Connecting to payment gateways
  • Sending delivery data to logistics providers
  • Communicating with AI/ML APIs

Example Use Cases for APIs in ABAP

Here are some real-world scenarios where ABAP developers use APIs:

1. Integrating SAP with a CRM

  • Send customer details to Salesforce or HubSpot using POST calls.

2. Fetching Live Data

  • Retrieve stock prices, exchange rates, or weather details in real time.

3. Automating External Processes

  • Send purchase order confirmations to vendor portals.

4. Connecting SAP to Cloud Applications

  • Use REST APIs to integrate SAP with cloud apps, chatbots, mobile apps, and dashboards.

Conclusion

  • In modern SAP landscapes, REST APIs are not just a concept—they are a necessity.

As an ABAP developer, understanding APIs empowers you to:

  • Build smarter integrations
  • Automate cross-platform workflows
  • Connect SAP with the outside world
  • Stay aligned with SAP’s shift toward cloud and digital transformation
  • This blog sets the foundation.

Stay tuned for Part 2 of the API series!

Your feedback and suggestions are always welcome. 😊

entry.title: Performance Optimization Strategies for Marketplace App Scenarios in SAP Commerce Cloud
entry.content:
I’m looking to gather insights and best practices on improving performance for marketplace-based applications built on SAP Commerce Cloud. Marketplace setups often introduce additional complexity—multiple sellers, high product volumes, heavy API usage, and dynamic pricing or inventory updates—which can significantly impact site speed and scalability.
In addition to SAP Commerce Cloud’s built-in tuning options, I’m also interested in how teams are leveraging Cloudflare to enhance overall performance, security, and stability.
Specifically, I’d like to hear about:

  • Proven performance optimization techniques for large-scale marketplace apps in SAP Commerce Cloud
  • Managing high traffic, seller onboarding, and large catalog structures efficiently
  • Cache strategies (platform-level, CDN-level, and Cloudflare-specific optimizations like caching rules, Workers, and edge functions)
  • How Cloudflare has helped reduce load, improve response times, or mitigate spikes in traffic
  • Handling API-heavy marketplace interactions with minimal latency
  • Any performance pitfalls you’ve encountered and how you addressed them


If you’ve tuned a marketplace system, integrated Cloudflare, or built performance monitoring pipelines, your experiences would be incredibly valuable.

entry.title: Query about non factory static action in RAP
entry.content:
I have a doubt regarding non factory static action defined in RAP (for this example, lets consider in RAP Managed).

So there is a list report, where an action button "IncreasePrice" is visible (even when none of the record is selected) as the action is defined as static. Till here , its fine.

Now when I go to implement the method for this action in behaviour implementation, I see there is importing parameter "keys" which contains only %cid. So I have the below questions now.

1) Since I have defined non factory static instance, which means its not for CREATION of instances and not applicable to a particular instance , then what is the use of this importing parameter "keys" which contains %cid ?

2) I observed that when i select , lets say 3 records from the list report and click on this action, the corresponding method gets triggered thrice, which is surprising for me because this is supposed to be a static action to be triggered on the entity level and not on instance level. Imagine if I am writing some logic to be applied at entity level, it will be called 3 times because of this , which is not expected from static action I think.

3) In the implementation method for this action, if I have to apply some change in value for all instances of this entity (something which is expected from a static action) , I guess I would need to loop through all the instances and use MODIFY Entities to do that.

  But to loop through the instances, I will need to maybe first READ all the instances in an itab using READ ENTITIES , however in READ ENTITIES we are supposed to give some where condition for keys and in this static action, I do not have anything apart from %cid in the importing parameter , so how do i READ all the records. (Or maybe there is some other way to do which I am unaware).

Thanks a lot in advance.

entry.title: Re: How to use 「Scrap in %」in Routing master
entry.content:
Good day @SONG_PANLONG 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references

Operation Scrap, Scrap Component Group Materials

Planned Cost (Preliminary Costing of Manufacturing Orders), Production Orders in Cost Object Controlling

In summary, the Scrap in % is used in public cloud when your operation is expected to produce some losses during processing (e.g., cutting operations). That means your planned quantity, component quantities and production cost calculation will be affected because it takes the Scrap in % into consideration. Scrap is tied to an operation and not the entire Bill of Materials for your final product. It is appropriate when only a specific routing step is responsible for the generation of waste.

On your question about how production order and production costs are affected, Scrap in % simply increases your input quantity, consumes more component and thereby increasing your cost of production. You can only see its impact after you have exploded the routing into your production order.

Below is a step-by-step guidance on how to view the Scrap in %

In your Manage Routings, search for a desired product

Open the Routing and find the General Data field. Here you will see the Scrap (%)

Under Components, you chan check if the system adjusted quantities if Scrap % was applied.

Finally go to the Create Production Order app, enter your details. Then check your component overview, your operations quantities and costing tab. There you will see increased consumption and recalculated costs.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Actual Cost Accounting and Moving Average Cost
entry.content:
Good morning sir , 

>Does SAP's actual cost accounting only calculate items with standard cost settings?

YES . 

>How are items with moving average cost settings calculated when they are mixed with other items?

Every time when the stock quantity or amount increased , unit price will be recalculated :
unit price = total amount / total quantity  

then when you do the goods issue , the cost will be based on the new unit price like :
COGS = goods issue quantity * unit price. 

 

please have a look at this blog for more details :
What Is the Difference Between Moving Average Price and Standard Price in SAP?

 

best regards 

Shi Zhekui

entry.title: Building a Production-Ready SAP Composable Storefront: Architecture, Best Practices & Blueprint
entry.content:
Introduction

As commerce landscapes evolve toward composability, frontend architectures must deliver speed, modularity, resilience, and seamless integration with enterprise ecosystems.
SAP Composable Storefront, built on Angular and powered by OCC APIs, offers a modern, headless, and flexible foundation for B2B/B2C experiences — but building it for production requires deliberate architectural choices and strong engineering discipline.

In this blog, I provide a practical and deeply technical blueprint for designing, implementing, and running a production-ready SAP Composable Storefront application. Whether you're an architect, senior engineer, or SAP Commerce integrator, these guidelines will help you scale efficiently, avoid common pitfalls, and achieve high performance on the edge.

1. Architectural Overview

SAP Composable Storefront is essentially an Angular application composed from Spartacus libraries with custom modules layered on top. It communicates with SAP Commerce Cloud via:

  • OCC REST APIs (product, cart, checkout, CMS)

  • Third-party services (identity, search, payments, analytics)

  • Edge/CDN layers (for caching & performance)

High-Level Flow

  1. User request hits the CDN. If an SSR HTML page is cached → return instantly.

  2. If not cached, request is forwarded to the SSR Node server pool.

  3. Once delivered, the Angular client hydrates and fetches additional data from Commerce APIs.

  4. Connectors, adapters, and interceptors handle mapping, authentication, and context (site/catalog/currency).

Design Goals

  • Modular, maintainable features

  • Clean separation of concerns

  • Efficient API mapping & error handling

  • Strong observability and operational readiness

  • High performance on edge delivery

2. Project Setup & Recommended Foundation

A solid foundation begins with the right scaffolding. The recommended project initialization:

ng new my-storefront --routing --style=scss
cd my-storefront
ng add /schematics --ssr

After running Spartacus schematics:

  • Configure environment.ts with occBaseUrl, site, and API prefix

  • Validate Commerce Cloud compatibility matrix

  • Choose feature libraries (B2B, Wishlists, CDS, CDC, etc.)

  • Establish a multi-env config strategy: dev / staging / prod / SSR / preview

3. Folder Structure & Module Strategy

A clean folder structure is critical for scalability in large storefront implementations.

src/
  app/
    core/         → interceptors, guards, root services
    shared/       → UI components, directives, pipes
    features/     → cart, product, checkout, account, etc.
    config/       → all Spartacus + application configs
    styles/       → SCSS tokens, global mixins, theming
  server/         → Angular Universal SSR code
  assets/         → images, i18n, icons

Core Principles

  • CoreModule contains all singletons.

  • SharedModule contains pure components, no business logic.

  • Feature Modules are route-based and lazily loaded.

  • Config Modules centralize Spartacus and custom configurations.

This organization prevents module bloat and ensures low coupling.

4. Theming, Styling & Asset Strategy

  • Use SCSS with centralized variables/tokens (_tokens.scss)

  • Prefer BEM methodology for predictable styling

  • Keep global styles minimal

  • Host large asset bundles on a CDN in production

  • Use WebP and responsive image sets for performance

  • Avoid overriding Spartacus styles excessively — extend, don’t fork

5. Data Flow: Connectors, Adapters & Mappers

SAP Composable Storefront’s architecture encourages clean data handling:

Best Practices

  • Keep raw OCC models in adapters

  • Map OCC → UI-friendly models in dedicated mappers

  • Use HTTP interceptors for:

    • Auth token injection

    • Site/tenant context headers

    • Request correlation IDs

  • Keep services thin; let adapters handle network concerns

  • Implement custom endpoints using Spartacus’ OccConfig extension approach

This ensures maintainability through upgrades and avoids code duplication.

6. State Management & RxJS Best Practices

Spartacus already ships with internal NgRx stores; custom state can extend it cleanly.

Guidelines

  • Prefer async pipes instead of manual subscription/unsubscription

  • Use OnPush change detection for all components

  • Apply correct RxJS operators:

    • switchMap → dependent API calls

    • exhaustMap → checkout flow steps

    • combineLatest → merged UI streams

  • Keep state local wherever possible — global store only when necessary

7. Server-Side Rendering (SSR) & Pre-Rendering

SSR is essential for SEO and for first-load performance of SAP storefronts.

Key SSR Considerations

  • Leverage Angular Universal for rendering

  • Pre-render static routes (homepage, category pages)

  • Implement fast fallback for SSR server failures

  • Always guard DOM access using:

if (isPlatformBrowser(this.platformId)) {
  // browser-only logic
}

Scaling SSR

  • Deploy SSR nodes behind a load balancer

  • Use horizontal autoscaling based on CPU/memory

  • Cache SSR HTML aggressively at the CDN

8. Performance, Caching & CDN Strategy

Recommendations

  • Use long cache TTLs with content-hashed asset filenames

  • Enable API-level caching for read-only endpoints (CMS, product, categories)

  • Implement lazy loading & route-based code splitting

  • Consider image optimization and responsive formats

  • Cache SSR output at CDN for key pages

  • Monitor TTFB and Core Web Vitals continuously

This significantly reduces backend loads and improves Lighthouse scores.

9. Security Considerations

  • Enforce HTTPS everywhere

  • Apply Content Security Policy (CSP) headers

  • Use HttpOnly cookies for tokens when possible

  • Sanitize CMS-driven HTML

  • Rate-limit OCC endpoints at the gateway layer

  • Avoid leaking internal config via environment files

Security must be treated as a continuous practice, not a one-time setup.

10. Testing Strategy

Layers of Testing

  • Unit tests → Services, components, mappers

  • Integration tests → Using Cypress or Playwright

  • Visual regression tests → Percy or Playwright snapshots

  • Contract tests → Pact against OCC

  • API mocks for local development

A mature storefront requires confidence across all layers.

11. CI/CD & Deployment Patterns

A modern pipeline should include:

  1. Linting

  2. Unit tests

  3. Build (client + server bundles)

  4. Integration/E2E tests

  5. Deploy to staging

  6. Canary/Blue-Green deployment

  7. Final production release

Infrastructure Guidance

  • SSR Nodes deployed in Kubernetes

  • Zero-downtime rolling updates

  • Automatic CDN cache invalidation on release

  • Tight integration with observability stack

12. Monitoring & Operational Runbook

Monitoring Stack

  • Error tracking (Sentry / Dynatrace / Kibana)

  • Node SSR logs with correlation IDs

  • Alerts for:

    • Memory pressure

    • 5xx spikes

    • Slow OCC endpoints

    • CDN cache miss patterns

Runbook Should Include

  • How to disable SSR in emergencies

  • Cache purge strategy

  • Rollback instructions

  • Recovering from Commerce outages

This ensures stable operations even under stress.

13. Extensibility, Upgrades & Governance

To keep the storefront healthy long-term:

  • Never fork Spartacus libraries

  • Maintain compatibility matrix with Commerce & Spartacus versions

  • Use linting + Angular style guide

  • Treat every new feature as an isolated module

  • Have a structured upgrade plan for both Angular & Spartacus versions

Good governance reduces technical debt dramatically.

Conclusion

Building a production-ready SAP Composable Storefront requires more than installing Spartacus libraries — it demands a carefully crafted architecture, operational excellence, and adherence to enterprise-grade engineering standards.

By following the patterns outlined above, teams can deliver storefronts that are:

  • Performant

  • Composable

  • Upgrade-friendly

  • Highly maintainable

  • Secure

  • Ready for enterprise scale

This blueprint aligns with SAP’s recommended best practices and equips teams to deliver future-proof digital commerce experiences.
